10:04 [narrator] Following in his grandfather's footsteps, ‎祖父にならい

12:16 It became almost impossible for him to make a living. ‎もはや生活は支えられません

12:24 but to leave Vishneva for Palestine, Eretz Israel, ‎行き先はパレスチナの ‎エレツ･イスラエル
12:28 where his brother and other family members had already moved. ‎兄弟や親せきが ‎すでに住んでいました

12:34 and send for his wife Sara and his sons once he was making enough money. ‎妻サラや息子たちを ‎呼び寄せる計画でした
12:40 Not long after Yitzhak's departure, ‎父の移住後まもなく
12:42 a member of the Jewish community was brutally murdered ‎地元の森で殺人が起きました
12:45 by an anti-Semitic gang in one of the nearby forests. ‎反ユダヤ集団の仕業です

12:54 All of us were alarmed. ‎皆 不安になりました
12:58 [narrator] So alarmed that they decided to leave for Palestine as soon as they could. ‎そして 早急にパレスチナへ ‎移る決断をします

14:10 [narrator] Sara, Shimon, and Gigi arrived in Jaffa Harbor via Istanbul in British Mandatory Palestine ‎３人はイギリス委任統治領 ‎ヤッファに到着しました

14:24 Nothing was alike in Jaffa and Vishneva. ‎故郷とは少しも似ていません

15:02 People were not dressed as heavily as we were. ‎人々は 私たちのように ‎厚着をせず

15:12 They were strong. ‎強‎靭(じん)‎な身体

15:29 It's like, you know, I was jumping from one world to another world. I couldn't believe it. ‎別の世界へ飛び移ったようで ‎信じられませんでした
15:36 I was reborn. And I was happy. ‎生まれ変わったようで ‎幸せでした
15:41 That I don't have the words to describe it. ‎言葉では 言い尽くせません
15:45 My dream came true, ‎夢が叶ったのです
15:48 and the dream was by far more beautiful, ‎その夢は ‎はるかに美しかった
15:53 more fascinating, more optimistic, more than I ever had dreamed. ‎想像よりもずっと魅力的で ‎楽観的なものでした
16:03 [narrator] Shimon enrolls in sixth grade at the Balfour School in Tel Aviv. ‎シモンは テルアビブの ‎バルフォア校６年に編入し
16:08 He immediately stands out among other students, ‎すぐに頭角を現しました

16:13 I knew Hebrew perfectly, ‎ヘブライ語は完璧でしたが

16:26 [Bar-Zohar] He wanted to be a sabra. He had an accent from which he didn't get rid until today, actually. ‎イスラエル出身者とは違う ‎訛りは抜けませんでした
16:33 And that was the one thing which he didn't like about my biography. ‎私の書いた伝記でも ‎その記述が気に入らず
16:38 He called me once and he said, "Who told you I have a Polish accent?" ‎“ポーランド訛りがあると ‎誰が言った？”と

16:51 Then he met a friend whose father convinced him その後 友だちの父親に 説得され

17:00 And then he saw his life, his future, in agriculture. ‎将来は農業に携わる ‎つもりでした
17:04 He says once he wanted to be a farmer ‎夢は 農業労働者または―
17:07 or a poet to the stars. ‎詩人だと言っていました
17:11 [narrator] "The most important service to the people of Israel ‎“この国に一番必要なのは”

17:20 "Why I Aspire to Study and Live in Ben Shemen." ‎題名 ‎“ベン･シェメンで学ぶ理由”

17:33 He also becomes a leader in one of the most popular Zionist youth movements in the country, ‎そしてシオニスト青年運動の ‎リーダーとなります
17:38 HaNoar HaOved, "The Working Youth." ‎“働く若者”という組織です
17:44 Shimon's activism soon brings him to the attention ‎その活動は注目されました

17:51 and perhaps the most important figure in labor Zionism, David Ben-Gurion. ‎労働シオニズムの重要人物 ‎ダヴィド･ベングリオンです

18:57 How did Trotsky enter the car at the last part of our voyage? I don't know. ‎なぜ急にトロツキーの話に ‎なったか分かりません
19:04 [narrator] Ben-Gurion then proceeded to lecture Shimon ‎そしてレーニンほど

19:42 [narrator] Sonya is the daughter of Ben Shemen's carpentry teacher, Yakov Gelman. ‎ソーニャは ベン･シェメンの ‎工芸教師の娘でした
19:48 [Bar-Zohar] He saw this girl coming out of the house with one of the teachers, ‎家から出てきたこの女性に ‎目がとまりました

20:00 and he looked at her and he fell in love. ‎ひと目ぼれでした
20:03 And that was total. He was very much in love. ‎激しい恋に落ちたのです
20:20 [narrator] October 1939. ‎1939年９月

22:58 So the group is risking arrest. ‎逮捕は覚悟の上でした

33:02 his main focus at the Israeli mission offices ‎しかし任務の主な目的は―
